description: Green gram, also known as mung bean, is a small, green legume in the Fabaceae family. It is cultivated for its edible seeds and sprouts, and is a traditional ingredient in many Asian cuisines. It is known for being easily digestible and nutritious.
localNames: Frijol Chino (Spanish - though often refers to sprouts)
seasons: Warm-season crop; typically planted in summer (Kharif season in India) or as a short-duration catch crop between main cereal harvests.
healthBenefits: Good source of plant-based protein and dietary fiber.
Easily digestible compared to some other legumes.
Rich in folate, manganese, and magnesium.
May help regulate blood sugar levels.
Contains antioxidants that can help protect against chronic diseases.

potentialAllergies.name: Legume Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: Allergy to mung beans is relatively uncommon but can occur, potentially causing oral allergy syndrome or other allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.

cultivationProcess: Green gram cultivation involves preparing a well-drained seedbed, sowing seeds, minimal fertilization (as it's a nitrogen-fixer), weed management, and harvesting when pods turn brown or black. It's a short-duration crop.
growthDuration: Approximately 60-90 days, making it suitable as a catch crop or for intercropping.
sustainabilityTips: Short life cycle allows it to fit well into crop rotations and utilize short rainfall periods.
carbonFootprintInfo: Green gram generally has a low carbon footprint due to its nitrogen-fixing ability, short duration, and low input requirements. It's a sustainable protein source.

staticRecipes.name: Simple Yellow Mung Dal (Split Mung Beans)
ingredients: 1 cup yellow split mung beans (moong dal), rinsed
instructions: Combine rinsed yellow mung dal, water, turmeric powder, and salt in a medium saucepan or pot.
Bring to a boil. Skim off any foam that rises to the surface.
Reduce heat to low, cover partially, and simmer for 15-25 minutes, or until the dal is soft and cooked through. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking. Add more water if it becomes too thick.
While dal is cooking, prepare the tempering. Heat ghee or oil in a small pan over medium heat.
Add cumin seeds and mustard seeds (if using). Let them splutter.
Add dried red chilies and asafoetida. Sauté for a few seconds. Add grated ginger if using and sauté for another 30 seconds.
Pour the hot tempering into the cooked dal. Stir well.
Simmer for another 2-3 minutes for flavors to meld.
Garnish with chopped fresh cilantro and serve hot with rice or roti.
staticRecipes.notes: Yellow split mung beans cook relatively quickly and become creamy. Adjust consistency as desired.

staticRecipes.name: Quick Mung Bean Sprouts Stir-fry
ingredients: 1/2 inch ginger, grated or thinly sliced
1/4 cup sliced bell peppers (any color, optional)
1 tbsp soy sauce (or tamari for gluten-free)
Salt and white pepper to taste
Optional garnish: toasted sesame seeds, chopped green onions
instructions: Rinse mung bean sprouts thoroughly. If they have long roots, you can pinch them off if desired.
Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat.
Add garlic and ginger, stir-fry for about 30 seconds until fragrant.
If using carrots or bell peppers, add them now and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes until slightly tender-crisp.
Add the mung bean sprouts to the wok. Stir-fry for 1-2 minutes. Sprouts cook very quickly and are best when still slightly crisp.
Add soy sauce, sesame oil, sugar (if using), salt, and white pepper. Toss everything together to combine well.
Cook for another 30 seconds to 1 minute.
Serve immediately, garnished with toasted sesame seeds or green onions if desired.
staticRecipes.notes: Do not overcook the sprouts, as they will become limp. This stir-fry is quick and best enjoyed fresh.

staticRecipes.name: Sweet Mung Bean Dessert (Kheer/Payasam Style)
ingredients: 1/2 cup yellow split mung beans (moong dal), rinsed
3 cups milk (dairy or non-dairy like coconut milk)
1/2 cup sugar (or jaggery, adjust to taste)
instructions: Optional: Dry roast the rinsed moong dal in a pan over low heat for 3-5 minutes until lightly golden and aromatic. This enhances flavor. Set aside.

In a heavy-bottomed pot, combine the roasted or plain moong dal with 1 cup of milk and 1 cup of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the dal is very soft and cooked through (about 20-25 minutes). Mash some of the dal against the side of the pot to thicken.
Add the remaining 2 cups of milk and sugar (or jaggery). Stir well and bring to a gentle simmer.
Cook on low heat for another 10-15 minutes, stirring frequently, until the dessert thickens to a creamy consistency. Add a little water or milk if it becomes too thick.
Stir in cardamom powder.
Optional Tempering: In a small pan, heat ghee or butter. Fry chopped nuts until golden. Add raisins and fry for a few seconds until they plump up. Pour this tempering over the dessert.
Serve warm or chilled.
staticRecipes.notes: This is a simplified version. Coconut milk can be used for a richer, distinct flavor. Jaggery will give a more traditional, earthy sweetness. Consistency can be adjusted to preference.

originAndDomesticationHistory: Green gram (Vigna radiata) was domesticated in India from its wild progenitor Vigna radiata var. sublobata. Archaeological evidence dates its cultivation back to around 4,500 years ago in the Indian subcontinent. It spread from India to other parts of Asia, Africa, and Australia.

climaticRequirements.temperature: Warm-season crop, preferring temperatures between 25-35°C. Sensitive to frost. High humidity can promote diseases.
climaticRequirements.rainfall: 300-500mm during the growing season. Drought-tolerant but performs best with consistent moisture, especially during flowering and pod formation. Tolerates short periods of waterlogging.
climaticRequirements.altitude: Typically grown in lowland areas, but can be cultivated up to 2000m in tropical and subtropical regions.

soilPreferences: Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy loam soils with a pH of 6.0-7.5. Can tolerate a range of soil types but not saline or highly alkaline conditions. Good aeration is beneficial.
irrigationAndWaterNeeds: Often grown rain-fed, especially during monsoon seasons. If irrigation is available, it's applied during critical stages like flowering and pod filling, particularly in drier conditions or for off-season cultivation.
plantingAndHarvestCycles: Usually sown at the onset of the rainy season or as a summer crop. Seeds are sown 2-4 cm deep. Pods mature unevenly, so multiple pickings might be done for fresh consumption, or plants are harvested when 70-80% of pods are mature (brown/black) for dry grain.
pestAndDiseaseManagement: Common pests include pod borers, aphids, thrips, and whiteflies (which can transmit yellow mosaic virus). Diseases include Mungbean Yellow Mosaic Virus (MYMV), Cercospora leaf spot, and powdery mildew. Integrated management involves resistant varieties, clean seeds, crop rotation, and need-based insecticide/fungicide application.
postHarvestHandling: Harvested plants are dried, then threshed to extract the seeds. Seeds are further cleaned and dried to a moisture content of 10-12% for storage. Stored in cool, dry places to prevent weevil infestation and mold.
marketValueAndGlobalDemand: Green gram is a major pulse crop in Asia, with high demand for both whole beans and split form (dal). It's valued for its nutritional content, easy digestibility, and quick cooking time. International trade exists but is less extensive than for some other pulses. Demand for sprouts is also significant globally.
